awd_titl_txt: 2022 GRC / GRS on Colloidal, Macromolecular, and Polyelectrolyte Solutions: Sub-title: “Connecting theory and simulations to experiments and applications.”
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide partial support for the 2022 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Colloidal, Macromolecular, and Polyelectrolyte Solutions: Connecting Theory and Simulations to Experiments and Applications, which will be held February 6-11, 2022 in Ventura, CA.  The conference will be preceded by a Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) for graduate students.  Together, the two events will provide opportunities for researchers, especially young investigators and students, to present results of their research, meet senior experts in the field, and discuss emerging research trends in colloidal and polymeric solutions.  These materials are important in a variety of technology areas including coatings, paints, personal-care products and cosmetics, and food processing.  The goal of the GRC and GRS is to bring promote discussions that will enable comparisons between experiments, numerical simulations, and theory for these important materials.

Colloidal and polymer science, including polyelectrolytes, is growing in importance in a wide range of applications, especially those involving biotechnology.  The development of RNA vaccines was enabled in part by creating nanoparticle complexes of DNA, a polyelectrolyte, with oppositely charged surfactants.  Synthetic structures that mimic cells, such as membraneless organelles, are formed by segregating charged proteins that exhibit polyelectrolyte phase behavior.  Increasing computing power, new computational methods, and high resolution experiments now allow comparisons between experiment and simulation at length and time scales that are accessible to both.  This is the theme of the GRC/GRS.  Session topics will include polyelectrolytes and ionic liquids, confined colloids, directed assembly, propelled colloids, interfacial systems, polymers and biology, polymer glasses, and driven elastomers.  The GRS for graduate students will include technical sessions as well as career development sessions for students and young investigators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF funding covered travel expenses for speakers and discussion leaders for the 2022 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Symposium (GRS) on Colloidal, Macromolecular, and Polyelectrolyte Solutions held from Nov. 5-6 (for GRS) and Nov. 6-10, 2022 (for GRC).  Our GRC involved a gathering of 117 scientists and graduate students and the GRS involved 34 students and 12 postdocs, from over 40 institutions, mostly academic, but also government labs and industry, to hear talks and engage in discussion on the conference topics. Gordon research conferences and symposiums are unique in emphasizing the most recent results and questions in the field, delivered through 22 carefully chosen speakers, who each spoke for 40 minutes, followed by 20 minutes of questions and discussion.  The choice of the site and the single session, as well as poster sessions, community dining, and afternoon breaks, all facilitate ample discussions and mixing of students and faculty of all seniorities, from graduate students, through Assistant, Associate, and Full Professors, as well as industrial speakers and participants.  The GRS, held on the weekend before the GRC consisted of a research talk by senior faculty member Kyle Bishop, as well as short talks introduced and moderated by faculty discussion leaders from academia and industry and poster sessions by graduate students. The meeting was capped by a panel discussion with three established researchers, representing industry (Macro Caggioni of Procter and Gamble), a national lab (Yun Liu of NIST), and academia (Danielle Mai of Stanford).  Most of the students that attended the GRS also attended the GRC, and carried their enthusiasm for science and research into the GRC.  This was manifested by the unusually large number of questions asked by students of the GRC speakers, with around half the 20-minute discussion period following each talk being taken by student questions.  Students testified that the GRS “warmed them up” and greatly reduced their fear of engaging in questions and discussions with senior researchers.  The 20-minute discussion period following every one of the 22 GRC talks were completely used up, with time used up before all raised hands could be responded to.  In the post-conference survey, when given a list of nine possible areas of improvement, 79% of the attendees found nothing at all that could be improved upon! Thus, the conference easily accomplished and exceeded its objectives of bringing top scientists of all ranks, Assistant Professor to Full Professor, from diverse institutions, of diverse ethnicity and gender, with seven of 22 speakers women.  A “power-hour” was held the afternoon of the first full day of the conference, led by the GRC co-chair Kelly Schultz of Lehigh University, aimed at encouraging and informing women scientists on pursuit of their careers.  The complete programs of the GRC and GRS can be found here:   https://www.grc.org/colloidal-macromolecular-and-polyelectrolyte-solutions-grs-conference/2022/  , https://www.grc.org/colloidal-macromolecular-and-polyelectrolyte-solutions-conference/2022/ .

 

Project Description

The topics of the Gordon conference are intrinsically highly inter-disciplinary, involving chemists, physicists, and materials scientists, engineering, and life sciences and medical researchers. Colloidal, macromolecular, and polyelectrolyte solutions are increasingly merging with biological areas of protein and DNA or RNA dynamics, as well as motility and self- propulsion. The increasing linkages between simulations and experiments was a prime area of focus for interdisciplinary work and discussions. The 2022 meeting included the fifth time a Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) for graduate students and early career investigators was held in conjunction with the meeting.

Intellectual merit. The topics of the conference are central to many of the leading questions in soft matter and complex fluids, including linkages to thermodynamics, structure, and transport of both synthetic and biological materials.  The fact that DNA, RNA, and proteins are all polyelectrolytes, and, that globular proteins and their complexes function as colloidal objects in the cell, testifies to the richness of physical and chemical phenomena and their linkages to some of the deepest questions in science, and to applications in areas of chemical manufacture, pharmaceuticals, and personal care products. The strong attendance (117) showed the keen interest in these topics and the value placed on the interactions by its participants.  

Broader impacts. The opportunity to gather for an intimate meeting with a high level of engagement was particularly needful at this time to re-launch the engagements that had been badly hampered over the past two and a half years of Covid. This need to meet was particularly true for the young scientists, students, and post-docs, whose loss of contact with the wider community has been especially harmful. Particularly helpful was the ample time for exchange and interaction of early career researchers with established and senior investigators in attendance for the full week and were available every meal time and poster session in a relaxed setting.
